contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox Officeholder | honorific-prefix = | name = Sir Joseph-Mathias Tellier | honorific-suffix = | image = Joseph-Mathias Tellier.png | office = Member of the [[Legislative Assembly of Quebec]] for [[Joliette (provincial electoral district)|Joliette]] | predecessor = [[Louis Basinet]] | successor = [[Ernest Hébert (MLA)|Ernest Hébert]] | term_start = 1892 | term_end = 1916 | office2 = [[List of leaders of the Official Opposition of Quebec|Leader of the Official Opposition of Quebec]] | predecessor2 = [[Pierre-Évariste Leblanc]] | successor2 = [[Philémon Cousineau]] | term_start2 = 1909 | term_end2 = 1915 | office3 = [[Chief Justice of Quebec]] | predecessor3 = [[Pierre-Eugène Lafontaine]] | successor3 = [[Séverin Létourneau]] | term_start3 = 1932 | term_end3 = 1942 | birth_date = {{birth date|1861|1|15}} | birth_place = Sainte-Mélanie, Canada East | death_date = {{death date and age|1952|10|18|1861|1|15}} | death_place = Joliette, Quebec | nationality = | spouse = | party = [[Conservative Party of Quebec (historical)|Conservative]] | relations = [[Louis Tellier]], brother | children = [[Maurice Tellier]] | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = | profession = | religion = }} '''Sir Joseph-Mathias Tellier''' (January 15, 1861 – October 18, 1952) was born in Sainte-Mélanie, [[Quebec]], [[Canada]]. ==Biography== He was a [[Conservative Party of Quebec (historical)|Quebec Conservative Party]] leader, but never premier. He was in the [[Legislative Assembly of Quebec]] from 1892 to 1916, as a Member for the riding of [[Joliette (provincial electoral district)|Joliette]] . After his studies at [[Université Laval]], he was admitted to the [[Barreau du Quebec]] and he practiced law for over 15 years. He was mayor of [[Joliette]] from 1903 to 1910, and, in 1916, he became a [[Quebec Superior Court]] [[judge]]. He was [[Chief Justice of Quebec]] from 1932 to 1942. He was made a Knight of the [[Order of Pius IX]] in 1906. He was Knighted by King [[George V]] in 1934. Sir Joseph-Mathias Tellier is the brother of [[Louis Tellier]], the father of [[Maurice Tellier]], the grandfather of [[Paul Tellier]], and a first cousin of Raymond Tellier, who is the grandfather of [[Luc-Normand Tellier]]. ==Elections as party leader== He lost the [[Quebec general election, 1912|1912 election]] against Sir [[Lomer Gouin]]. ==See also== *[[List of Quebec leaders of the Opposition]] ==References== *{{QuebecMNAbio|tellier-joseph-mathias-5493}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Tellier, Joseph-Mathias | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Canadian politician | DATE OF BIRTH = January 15, 1861 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = October 18, 1952 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tellier, Joseph-Mathias}} [[Category:1861 births]] [[Category:1952 deaths]] [[Category:Canadian knights]] [[Category:Conservative Party of Quebec MNAs]] [[Category:Judges in Quebec]] [[Category:Knights Bachelor]] [[Category:Knights of Pius IX]] [[Category:Lawyers in Quebec]] [[Category:Mayors of places in Quebec]] [[Category:Quebec political party leaders]] [[Category:Université Laval alumni]] {{Conservative-Quebec-MNA-stub}} {{Quebec-mayor-stub}}
